bibl.title: Partial letter from [Paul L. Tate] to William M. Brumby, [1954]

div1.p: [Tate] thinks it is a shame that worthy men such as Finlay, Ames, and Lambert were not included in the Yellow Fever Roll of Honor.

div1.head: Partial letter from [Paul L. Tate] to William M. Brumby, [1954]
div1.p: From a letter to Doctor W.M. Brumby

To produce a complete, comprehensive account such as the yel-
low experiments in Cuba, one must know the personal experi-
ence of many of those who took part in, or observed it.

The part that Doctor Finlay, whose theories were the primary
cause of the experiments with the mosquito as the carrier are
well known. Major Reed's work has been fully covered. The con-
nection with the experiment of General Wood, Major Kean, the
Surgeon General and others are also well known and, while
very important, had little impact on the actual experiment.
They did what any men in their positions would have done.

General Truby has well presented all he knew of it in the
best book yet written about it. But he was there but a short
time, and not at all when Camp Lazear was running, so there
was much that he missed.

What were the thoughts anactions and actions of the decis-
ive character in the whole experiment; the man who alone sol-
ved the mystery, Lazear, are unknown, owing to his untimely
death from yellow fever blood injection. They will never be
known, as he kept no records except the mystic numbers in the
little note-book which Major Reed was able to solve and from
them form the basis for the experiment to prove his findings.

A big mistake was made when the names were presented for
honors by Congress in 1929, was the excluding of Doctor Fin-
lay, whose previous findings, plain as they were, had been
unrecognized by blind doctors for 19 years, and on whose
evidence these experiments were begun by Major Reed. Of course
Lazear would have naturally turned to the mosquito on account
of his experience with them in transmitting malaria, but Fin-
lay was of great help.

Agramonte had to be honored as a member of the Board although
he in no way helped the experiment and was seldom there, while
Finlay's assistance was invaluable. I hope that when Doctor
Hench writes his book he will see his way to emphasize Finlay's
help. I think that the non-recognition of Finlay by the 1929
Congress was a grave error, and is accountable for much of
the bitterness of certain classes of the Cubans today.

It is too bad that Act of Congress is a closed book and that
more deserving men, such as Finlay, Ames and Lambert cannot
be included. Compare their invaluable services to taht of
Hammann, Bullard, Covington, who were in the later experiments
months after the main theory had been proven, and yet were
honored by Congress.
